intro: Castilleja citrina, commonly known as the yellow milkvetch, is a hemiparasitic flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Orobanchaceae family and is characterized by its yellow-orange flowers that bloom in late spring. The plant has a slender, branching stem and small, lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. It typically grows in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and sagebrush steppe. Castilleja citrina forms symbiotic relationships with certain fungi, which help it obtain nutrients from the soil.
